column1: Lackawanna is a city in Erie County
column2: New York
column3: United States just south of the city of Buffalo in the western part of New York state. The population was 18
column4: 141 at the 2010 census.  It is part of the Buffalo-Niagara Falls metropolitan area. The city of Lackawanna is in the county's southwestern part.

column1: The town's name derives from the Lackawanna Steel Company. During the early 20th century
column2: the Lackawanna steel plant was the largest in the world.

column1: The city of Lackawanna has a mayor-council form of government. A councilmember is elected from each of the four wards of the city
column2: considered single-member districts. The mayor and council president are elected at-large. Fire and police services are also provided by city-run departments.Because of its resemblance to a popular mid-20th century west coast building type
column3: Lackawanna's burnt-orange city hall is distinctive for possibly being the only dingbat city hall in the United States.

column1: Originally part of the Buffalo Creek Reservation
column2: the area was not open to settlement until 1842 when the land was sold by the Seneca Indians. In 1851 the town of Seneca was formed; the name was changed to West Seneca in 1852. The area now known as Lackawanna was then called West Seneca or Limestone Hill.

column1: Lackawanna was a center of steel manufacture throughout most of the 20th century. In 1899 all the land along the West Seneca shore of Lake Erie was purchased by the Lackawanna Steel Company
column2: based in Scranton
column3: Pennsylvania since its founding. Construction was started in 1900 and the Lackawanna Steel Company relocated to the area in 1902. The plant began operations in 1903. Later
column5: the residents of the area voted to split off from West Seneca
column6: forming the city of Lackawanna.In 1922 the Lackawanna Steel Company was acquired by the Bethlehem Steel Company. With the 20th-century growth of the Bethlehem Steel plant
column7: at one time the largest in the world
column8: came the continued growth of the city and its institutions. At its peak the plant employed 20
column9: 000 people. It attracted immigrants from many lands to settle here and make their homes. Due to industrial restructuring in the latter half of the 20th century and arbitrary property tax assessment increases levied on the plant by the town
column10: the steel plant declined in business and eventually closed in 1983
column11: following massive job layoffs.In the 21st century
column12: efforts have been made to develop the former steel plant brownfields to other uses. The site has a diversity of tenants
column13: some occupying buildings remaining from the former steel plant and a few in newer buildings. Opponents say that the brownfield is not safe and that alleged contamination of the field has caused cancer and other medical issues. United States Environmental Protection Agency reports are still ongoing and contested.As part of redevelopment
column14: wind turbines were built on the former Bethlehem Steel property in 2007. These initial eight 2.5 megawatt turbines will provide power for up to 9
column15: 000 households and are considered a sustainable energy source.The Buffalo Harbor South Entrance Light was listed on the National Register of Historic Places in 2007.On November 9
column17: a major fire broke out at the former galvanizing plant of the Bethlehem Steel complex.

column2: Lackawanna and Western Railroad
column3: originally the Lackawanna and Western Railroad
column4: operated from 1851 to 1960. In 1960 it was consolidated with the Erie Railroad to become the Erie Lackawanna Railway. This operated until 1976
column5: when it was absorbed by Conrail.

column1: The city of Lackawanna was the defendant in the 1971 district court decision Kennedy-Park Homes Association v. City of Lackawanna. This decision forbade the municipal government (Lackawanna) from interfering with the construction of a low-income housing development in a predominantly white section of the city. The court ruled such action would amount to racial discrimination.

The Lackawanna Six (also known as the Buffalo Six) are a group of Yemeni Americans who were convicted of providing "material support" to Al-Qaeda. The group was accused of traveling to Afghanistan and Pakistan in the spring of 2001 to attend terrorist training camps. The men had claimed that their travel was to Pakistan only
column2: and for the purpose of religious instruction.

column1: The group was arrested in Lackawanna on September 13
column3: by the FBI. A member of the Lackawanna Cell
column5: never returned to the U.S. after his trip to Afghanistan. In September 2003 the FBI announced a $5 million reward for information leading to his arrest. Captured by Yemen police
column6: he was convicted and sentenced to a prison in Yemen for involvement in the 2002 bombing of the French oil tanker Limburg off the coast of Yemen. The remaining members of the group pleaded guilty in December 2003 and were given various sentences in federal prison.Jaber Elbaneh escaped from a Yemeni prison in 2006 after joining a successful group prison break. He was identified as one of 23 people
column12: as they issued a national press release naming Elbaneh to the FBI Most Wanted Terrorists list. On May 20
column14: Elbaneh turned himself in to Yemen authorities on the condition that his prison sentence would not be extended. The incident of the Lackawanna Six has tarnished the city's reputation
column16: it was reported that prior to authorities sending in 130 federal and local members of the Western New York Joint Terrorism Task Force
column17: there were suggestions that federal troops be used to capture the suspects. At the time
column18: Vice President Dick Cheney and Defense Secretary Donald Rumsfeld believed that the Yemeni men should be declared enemy combatants and could have been tried by a military tribunal. President Bush rejected this proposal
column19: and the arrests proceeded without incident.

column1: Father Baker's social programs have evolved into Baker Victory Services
column2: which care for more than 2
column3: 500 children each day. Baker Victory Services Adoption Program has evolved into a renowned resource for a wide range of adoptive services. Their mission is to assist birth mothers
column4: families and adoptees through the often complex and always emotional adoption process. Our Lady of Victory Hospital
column6: is being converted into senior housing. The Homes of Charity provide the funds to continue Baker's social programs through donations.

column1: Our Lady of Victory Basilica had its 75th anniversary in 2001. The Catholic Church named Father Baker a "Servant of God" in 1987
column2: the first step towards declaring him a saint. In 1999
column3: Father Baker's remains were moved from Holy Cross Cemetery and re-interred inside the basilica. This was a recommended step for his canonization process. On January 14
column5: Pope Benedict XVI approved a document of the Congregation for the Causes of Saints declaring Father Baker "Venerable."  His cause for canonization

continues under review by Vatican officials.


== Geography ==
The city has a total area of 6.6 square miles (17.1 km2), of which 0.04 square miles (0.1 km2), or 0.75%, is water. Lackawanna sits on Lake Erie, although the waterfront is occupied by the remnants of the Bethlehem Steel facility. Smokes Creek (named after Seneca Indian Chief Sayenqueraghta who was nicknamed Old Smoke") runs through the city before it discharges into Lake Erie.
